TITLE: Collaborative Proposal: The XENON Dark Matter Project: Construction and Underground Operation of a 100 kg Detector

ABSTRACT

The discovery of dark matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and particle physics. Despite the extreme challenges, the search for Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) believed to constitute the dark matter, continues with accelerator, space and underground based experiments. Ultimately, only astrophysical observations can determine whether WIMPs exist in nature, but the importance of direct detection of WIMP-nucleus scattering in laboratory experiments is well recognized. The US is in a world-leading position in direct detection; however, better-sensitivity experiments with sizeable increase in target mass and sophisticated background rejection schemes are key to future progress and discovery.

This award provides support to the Columbia and Rice groups for their continuation of the XENON Dark Matter Program, with the construction of a 100 kg fiducial mass detector (XENON100). The sensitivity goal is 2x10^45 cm^2. This is achieved through background discrimination provided by the simultaneous detection of ionization and scintillation signals in pure liquid xenon. XENON100 is built on the design and technology established with the XENON10 prototype, with a factor of ~10 increase in total Xe mass. XENON100 is an experiment that can be built with minimum risk, giving first physics results by 2009, when the LHC will be searching for Supersymmetric dark matter.

Among the Broader Impacts of this work, the XENON science has all the ingredients to captivate the interest and imagination of students and the general public alike. XENON technical-related work can impact society in a number of ways. The liquid xenon imaging detector technology is a prime candidate for applications in several fields outside particle astrophysics, including national security and medical imaging research.

Project Outcome Report – XENON100 Dark Matter Search

 

The XENON Dark Matter project aims at uncovering the nature of Dark Matter through direct detection of its interactions with xenon nuclei. Dark Matter constitutes about 85% of all matter in the universe, with the remaining 15% being the regular matter we are familiar with. Understanding the nature of Dark Matter, thought to be a new type of elementary particle, is considered one of the foremost questions in physics today. Whereas we compute that some 100,000 Dark Matter particles cross every square centimeter of our bodies every second, we have not been able to detect these particles other than through their gravitational impact on galaxies, galaxy clusters, and the evolution of the observable universe.

 

This grant enabled collaborative research by the US groups at Columbia University in the City of New York, NY, Rice University in Houston, TX, and the University of California in Los Angeles, CA, together with European collaborators, to design, build, and commission a second generation of XENON detectors, called XENON100. This experiment succeeds and surpasses by far the previously very successful XENON10. The XENON Dark Matter project has developped a so-called dual phase liquid/gas xenon time projection chamber, a position- and energy-sensitive detector that can distinguish between the nuclear recoils expected from Dark Matter interactions and the background interactions from energetic gamma-rays with the electrons of the atomic shell. This detector is cooled down to -95° C, where inert xenon gas liquefies at a pressure of about 2 bar. This clear liquid is not only a dense medium, about three times heavier than water, but also an excellent scintillator and a medium for ionization. The primary scintillation photons are detected immediately by arrays of photomultiplier tube, which are photodetectors that are sensitive to indivual light photons. The electrons released in a Dark Matter interaction are drifted across up to 30 cm before they are extracted into the gas phase by a strong electric field. Here they excite the atoms in the gas to scintillate abundantly, which allows measurement of the amount of charge and the location of the interaction.

 

Within the period of this grant, this new experiment XENON100 has become the leading experiment for Dark Matter direct searches in the world today, and continues to improve our knowledge about new physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics, as we continue to search for Dark Matter interactions. Together with the experiments at the giant accelerator Large Hadron Collider and indirect searches for Dark Matter, XENON100 is a key player in the search for the Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that are thought to constitute the bulk of Dark Matter in the universe. Will XENON100 discover Dark Matter?
